qas.question: What kind of criteria frequently used in science complicates the definitiveness of some hypotheses' falsification?
What other flaws complicate the problem of identifying faulty scientific hypotheses?
According to Popper, what resolves conflicting hypotheses and observations in the long run?
What is always possible to do?

plausible_answers.text: this is a sign of flaws in the hypothesis

qas.question: What is always clear if evidence contradicts a hypothesis?
Who wrote a set of instructions that merely need to be followed diligently to achieve science?

plausible_answers.text: resolution of conflicts between hypotheses and observations

qas.question: What is a matter of the judgement of a single scientist?
What is a sign of flaws in the evidence?

context: Another objection is that it is not always possible to <b3_0>demonstrate falsehood definitively<b3_0/>, especially if one is using <a0_0>statistical<a0_0/> criteria to evaluate a null hypothesis. More generally it is not always clear, if <b7_0>evidence contradicts a hypothesis<b7_0/>, that <b4_0>this is a sign of flaws in the hypothesis<b4_0/> rather than of <a1_0>flaws in the evidence<a1_0/>. However, this is a misunderstanding of what Popper's philosophy of science sets out to do. Rather than offering a set of instructions that merely need to be followed diligently to achieve science, <b5_0>Popper<b5_0/> makes it clear in The Logic of Scientific Discovery that his belief is that the <b6_0>resolution of conflicts between hypotheses and observations<b6_0/> can only be a matter of <a2_0>the collective judgment of scientists<a2_0/>, in each individual case.
